Articles.Content:
Can Kerbal Space Program work on 256 MB VRAM? Thanks

 

Thank you for the people who have answered the question and I read over each one.

Edited March 23, 2016 by beezTEM
Moved to Technical Support as it's a technical question.

The minimum amount of VRAM is 512MB.

However, as KSP does not rely so much on graphics memory as it does the CPU, you might be okay, if your CPU's good. Would you mind posting the rest of your system specs?

Edited March 16, 2016 by spink00
would you?

My computer is:

2.4 ghz dual core processor (I think)

Nividia Geforce (Don't know what model)

Built In sound card

Sorry but I don't know the rest

Edited March 18, 2016 by beezTEM

To get your computer specs:

Hold the "Windows" key and push "R" this will bring up the run command. Now in the field displayed type "dxdiag" without the quotes. That will bring up a box with all your system information, hit the button on the bottom of the box that says "save all information" this will turn it into a text or notepad file, which you should save somewhere convenient like your desktop.

Then simply open the notepad file, copy the text, and paste it here. Preferably under a spoiler as it will be rather large.

When your done it'll look like this:

The minimum amount of VRAM is 512MB.

4 hours ago, Rocket In My Pocket said:

To get your computer specs:

Hold the "Windows" key and push "R" this will bring up the run command. Now in the field displayed type "dxdiag" without the quotes. That will bring up a box with all your system information, hit the button on the bottom of the box that says "save all information" this will turn it into a text or notepad file, which you should save somewhere convenient like your desktop.

Then simply open the notepad file, copy the text, and paste it here. Preferably under a spoiler as it will be rather large.

Shared memory..... there's your problem.
So can I play or not?

It is actually possible to play KSP on a machine that doesn't have any VRAM.  I used to play it on a 2.16GHz CoreDuo laptop with 3GB of RAM running 32 bit windows (so KSP is limited to 2GB of RAM) and a NVidia Quadro NVS 110M that used shared memory.  I had to reduce the texture quality (to reduce the memory usage) and tweak various other graphics settings to get a reasonable frame rate, it still wasn't very quick, but it does run.

I also regularly play it on machines using an integrated Intel HD3000 or HD4000 that again doesn't have dedicated VRAM.  When I replaced the above laptop with an i7-4770K I initially had no graphics card but the integrated Intel HD still had a G3DMark 13x higher than the laptop...

Your GeForce 9200 has a G3DMark quite a bit higher than my old laptop (83 vs 46, see http://www.videocardbenchmark.net/low_end_gpus.html) so I would expect it to work though it will run quite slowly...

Edit: Here is the dxdiag from my old laptop for comparison with yours.  It actually reports 121MB of dedicated video memory so it probably has 128MB of VRAM.

Thank you and I might not get the full game anyway because as some people may say, "My computer sucks", but it was one of the best ones you could buy at the time.

WIth version 1.0.5 or earlier, it is single-thread CPU performance which is most important. Your CPU's single thread performance is about half that of the fastest current processors, but it is still not too bad. My eight Xeon cores have a lower single-thread performance than your CPU, and I'm fine most of the time as long as I keep part count under about 275 or so (but that said, I have about 50-80 flights on the go at any given time in career and that does slow everything else down too, both in flight and on every loading screen, despite using an SSD so it is really the CPU which is the bottleneck there).

Shared video memory is bad, but your total RAM is more than the maximum that 1.0.5 can actually use, so you'll have spare RAM for video as long as the game and your drivers play well together. Be prepared to turn down options.

The main future problem will be the switch to version 1.1, which (everyone keeps saying) will finally provide 64-bit support in Windows/OSX and multi-threading. That should be good news for me (but only relatively - my 4-core chips have a benchmark of 4135 each, which pales in comparison to an i7-4790K with a benchmark exceeding 11k) but not really for your Core2 Duo (benchmarked at just over 2k). I have no idea what the minimum video specs will be...
